## Slide 26

Highlights of Development Trends

Installation of first clinical scanner at Atkinson-Morleyâ€™s hospital by Hounsfield and Ambrose

Consisted of an x-ray tube and two detectors

Initially the scan time was about 5 minutes per slice

Digital data was recorded on a magnetic tape and was sent to a factory for overnight reconstruction

Upon return to the hospital the images were printed as an array of numbers

## Slide 27

The first publication of a grey scale image by Hounsfield and Ambrose

The image was of a brain of a living  patient

Showed a cystic lesion in the frontal lobe

This was followed by a popular exhibit at the 1972 RSNA  (Radiological Society of North America) annual meeting  in Chicago

## Slide 28

The original scanner was updated with its own microprocessor

It reduced the data acquisition time and the reconstruction time to 4.5 minutes each.

The smallest detail that could e visualized was about 3mm

Fist whole body scanner installed at Georgetown University Washington

Introduction of the 2nd generation scanners using 3 detectors.

## Slide 29

Use of Scanners with more detectors up to 30, and with reduced scan times up to 20 seconds.

A ring of detectors is employed resulting scan times down to 5 seconds.

EMI left the field of CT, while other companies enter into market producing scanners with more detectors from 280 t0 2400 reducing scan times to 2 seconds and with resolution of 0.4mm.

## Slide 30

Goitein and Abrams described multidimensional treatment planning based on CT images using a Beams eye view created from a divergent projection through the CT study data

Continuous rotation slip ring technology was introduced

After a brief hiatus, during which MRI stole the limelight, CT came back with vengeance.

Time was cut down to one second scanning.

The use of CT data for treatment planning increased and began top influence the total radiation oncology treatment planning effort.
